{{short description|Favoritism granted to relatives or close friends}} {{Use dmy dates|date=June 2021}} [[File:Benjamin Harrison Astley Cooper.jpg|thumb|right|[[Benjamin Harrison (hospital administrator)|Benjamin Harrison]], treasurer of Guy's Hospital in London, was shown as a dominant presiding figure, with the nepotism of Sir Astley Cooper having his tacit approval.]] {{Political corruption sidebar}} {{Discrimination sidebar|expand-social=yes}}
'''Nepotism''' is the act of granting an [[In-group favoritism|advantage]], privilege, or position to [[Kinship|relatives]] or close friends in an occupation or field. These fields may include but are not limited to: business, politics, academia, entertainment, sports, religion, and other activities.<ref>{{cite dictionary |entry-url=https://dictionary.cambridge.org/dictionary/english/nepotism |entry=nepotism |dictionary=Cambridge Dictionary |access-date=23 July 2021 |title=NEPOTISM | meaning in the Cambridge English Dictionary |archive-date=12 November 2020 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201112042128/https://dictionary.cambridge.org/dictionary/english/nepotism |url-status=live }}</ref><ref>{{cite dictionary |entry-url=https://www.dictionary.com/browse/nepotism |entry=nepotism |dictionary=Dictionary.com |access-date=23 July 2021 |title=Archived copy |archive-date=16 May 2021 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20210516040552/https://www.dictionary.com/browse/nepotism |url-status=live }}</ref> The term originated with the assignment of nephews to important positions by Catholic popes and bishops.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.catholic-forum.com/Saints/ncd05726.htm |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070224025607/http://www.catholic-forum.com/Saints/ncd05726.htm |archive-date=24 February 2007 |website=New Catholic Dictionary |title=nepotism}}</ref>
Nepotism has been criticized since [[ancient history]] by several philosophers, including [[Aristotle]], [[Thiruvalluvar|Valluvar]], and [[Confucius]], condemning it as both evil and unwise.<ref name="PSSundaram_Kural">{{cite book | last = Sundaram | first = P. S. | title = Tiruvalluvar: The Kural | publisher = Penguin Books | edition = First | date = 1990 | location = Gurgaon | pages = 12 | isbn = 978-0-14-400009-8 }}</ref>
== Origins == {{Main|Cardinal-nephew}} The term comes from Italian word ''nepotismo'',<ref name="dictionary">[http://dictionary.reference.com/browse/nepotism "Nepotism."] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160125235043/http://dictionary.reference.com/browse/nepotism |date=25 January 2016 }} Dictionary.com. Retrieved 20 June 2013.</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=In Praise of Nepotism: A Natural History |work=[[Adam Bellow]] Booknotes interview transcript |url=http://booknotes.org/Transcript/?ProgramID=1742 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100926013727/http://booknotes.org/Transcript/?ProgramID=1742 |archive-date=26 September 2010 |access-date=10 September 2013}}</ref> which is based on Latin root ''nepos'' meaning nephew.<ref>{{cite web |title=Article nepos |work=CTCWeb Glossary |url=http://www.ablemedia.com/ctcweb/glossary/glossaryn.html#nepos |access-date=10 September 2013 |archive-date=8 April 2000 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20000408143615/http://www.ablemedia.com/ctcweb/glossary/glossaryn.html#nepos |url-status=live }}</ref> Since the [[Middle Ages]] and until the late 17th century, some [[Catholicism|Catholic]] popes and bishops – who had taken vows of [[chastity]] and, therefore, usually had no legitimate offspring of their own – gave their nephews such positions of preference as were often accorded by fathers to sons.<ref name="Article Nepotism">{{cite web|title=Article Nepotism |work=New Catholic Dictionary |url=http://catholic-forum.com/saints/ncd05726.htm |access-date=12 July 2007 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070224025607/http://www.catholic-forum.com/Saints/ncd05726.htm |archive-date=24 February 2007 }}</ref>
Several popes [[Cardinal-nephew|elevated nephews]] and other relatives to the [[Cardinal (Catholicism)|cardinalate]]. Often, such appointments were a means of continuing a papal "dynasty".<ref>{{cite book|author1=Gianvittorio Signorotto|author2=Maria Antonietta Visceglia|title=Court and Politics in Papal Rome, 1492–1700|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=2W1tc-wf5DQC&pg=PA114|access-date=20 June 2013|date=21 March 2002|publisher=Cambridge University Press|isbn=978-1-139-43141-5|pages=114–116}}</ref> For instance, [[Pope Callixtus III]], head of the [[House of Borgia|Borgia]] family, made two of his nephews cardinals; one of them, Rodrigo, later used his position as a cardinal as a stepping stone to the papacy, becoming [[Pope Alexander VI]].<ref>{{cite web |title=Article Pope Alexander VI |work=New Catholic Dictionary |url=http://www.newadvent.org/cathen/01289a.htm |access-date=12 July 2007 |archive-date=1 May 2012 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120501192839/http://www.newadvent.org/cathen/01289a.htm |url-status=live }}</ref> Alexander then elevated Alessandro Farnese, his mistress's brother, to cardinal; Farnese would later go on to become [[Pope Paul III]].<ref>{{cite encyclopedia |title=Article Pope Paul III |encyclopedia=Catholic Encyclopedia |url=http://www.newadvent.org/cathen/11579a.htm |access-date=12 July 2007 |archive-date=1 May 2012 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120501215904/http://www.newadvent.org/cathen/11579a.htm |url-status=live }}</ref>
Paul III also engaged in nepotism, appointing, for instance, two nephews, aged 14 and 16, as cardinals. The practice was finally limited when [[Pope Innocent XII]] issued the [[Papal bull|bull]] ''[[Romanum decet Pontificem]]'', in 1692.<ref name="Article Nepotism"/> The papal bull prohibited popes in all times from bestowing estates, offices, or revenues on any relative, with the exception that one qualified relative (at most) could be made a cardinal.<ref>{{cite book|author=Anura Gurugé|title=The Next Pope|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=B5JVthemvvwC&pg=PA115|access-date=20 June 2013|date=16 February 2010|publisher=Anura Guruge|isbn=978-0-615-35372-2|page=115}}</ref>
===Mention in ancient literature=== In the [[Book of Porul|second book]] of the [[Tirukkural|Kural literature]], which forms a manual for governments and corporations, [[Valluvar]] suggests about nepotism and favouritism thus: "If you choose an unfit person for your job just because you love and you like him, he will lead you to endless follies."<ref>{{Cite web |url=https://knowledge.wharton.upenn.edu/article/rediscovering-a-management-and-leadership-manual-in-ancient-indian-literature/ |title=Rediscovering a Management and Leadership Manual in Ancient Indian Literature – Knowledge@Wharton<!-- Bot generated title --> |access-date=4 February 2023 |archive-date=17 November 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20221117054622/https://knowledge.wharton.upenn.edu/article/rediscovering-a-management-and-leadership-manual-in-ancient-indian-literature/ |url-status=live }}</ref> According to him, nepotism is both evil and unwise.<ref name="PSSundaram_Kural"/>
== Types == === Political === Nepotism is a common accusation in politics when the relative of a powerful figure ascends to similar power seemingly without appropriate qualifications. The [[British English]] expression "[[Bob's your uncle]]" is thought to have originated when [[Robert Arthur Talbot Gascoyne-Cecil, 3rd Marquess of Salisbury]], promoted his nephew, [[Arthur Balfour]], to the esteemed post of [[Chief Secretary for Ireland]], which was widely seen as an act of nepotism.<ref name=Trahair>[https://books.google.com/books?id=K0zrsHO27-wC&pg=PA72&lpg=PA72 ''From Aristotelian to Reaganomics: A Dictionary of Eponyms With Biographies in the Social Science''], by R. C. S. Trahair, [[Greenwood Publishing Group]], 1994, p. 72. Retrieved online from [[Google Books]], 30 July 2012.</ref>
=== Organizational === Nepotism in organizations leads to monopolization of power because when members involved in institutional decision-making are related, decisions made within institutions risk favoring a group of closely connected people.<ref>{{Cite journal |last1=Teixeira da Silva |first1=Jaime A. |last2=Katavić |first2=Vedran |last3=Dobránszki |first3=Judit |last4=Al-Khatib |first4=Aceil |last5=Bornemann-Cimenti |first5=Helmar |date=2019 |title=Establishing Rules for Ethicists and Ethics Organizations in Academic Publishing to Avoid Conflicts of Interest, Favoritism, Cronyism and Nepotism |url=http://komejournal.com/files/KOME_MS_rulesethicists.pdf |journal=KOME |volume=7 |issue=1 |pages=110–125 |doi=10.17646/KOME.75698.87 |s2cid=182521936 |access-date=4 February 2023 |archive-date=17 December 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20221217020813/http://komejournal.com/files/KOME_MS_rulesethicists.pdf |url-status=live }}</ref>
Nepotism can also occur within organizations, when a person is employed due to their familial ties.<ref>{{Cite journal|last1=Hotho|first1=Jasper|last2=Minbaeva|first2=Dana|last3=Muratbekova-Touron|first3=Maral|last4=Rabbiosi|first4=Larissa|date=1 September 2020|title=Coping with Favoritism in Recruitment and Selection: A Communal Perspective|journal=Journal of Business Ethics|language=en|volume=165|issue=4|pages=659–679|doi=10.1007/s10551-018-4094-9|issn=1573-0697|doi-access=free}}</ref> It is generally seen as unethical, both on the part of the employer and employee.<ref>"Richard Utz, "Beyond Consanguinity," ''[https://www.insidehighered.com/advice/2010/03/24/beyond-consanguinity Inside Higher Ed] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20221015131350/https://www.insidehighered.com/advice/2010/03/24/beyond-consanguinity |date=15 October 2022 }}'', 24 March 2010.</ref> One of the consequences of nepotism in an organization is the creation of a limitation in the organization's network of contacts, reducing the opportunities for negotiation with other social circles, which can lead to a reduction in the success and duration of organizations in the long term.<ref>{{Cite book |title=The handbook of business and corruption: cross-sectoral experiences |date=2017 |editor=Michael S. Aßländer |editor2=Sarah Hudson |isbn=978-1-78635-445-7 |location=Bingley, UK |oclc=1003263368}}</ref>
==== In employment ==== Nepotism at work can mean increased opportunity at a job, attaining a job or being paid more than other similarly situated people.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.safeworkers.co.uk/nepotismatwork.html |title=Nepotism at Work |publisher=Safeworkers.co.uk |date=20 April 2013 |access-date=20 June 2013 |archive-date=4 April 2019 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20190404005247/http://www.safeworkers.co.uk/NepotismAtWork.html |url-status=live }}</ref> Arguments are made both for and against employment granted due to a family connection, which is most common in small, [[family business|family run businesses]]. On one hand, nepotism can provide stability and continuity. Critics cite studies that demonstrate decreased morale and commitment from non-related employees,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.insideindianabusiness.com/contributors.asp?id=1625 |title=Family Ties: Handling Nepotism Within Your Business – Perspectives – Inside INdiana Business with Gerry Dick |publisher=Insideindianabusiness.com |date=9 November 2010 |access-date=20 June 2013 |archive-date=14 May 2013 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130514022519/http://www.insideindianabusiness.com/contributors.asp?id=1625 |url-status=live }}</ref> and a generally negative attitude towards superior positions filled through nepotism. An article from ''[[Forbes]]'' magazine stated "there is no ladder to climb when the top rung is reserved for people with a certain name."<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.forbes.com/2009/06/19/ceo-executive-hiring-ceonewtork-leadership-nepotism.html |title=Is Nepotism So Bad? |work=Forbes |access-date=20 June 2013 |first=Klaus |last=Kneale |archive-date=9 October 2019 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20191009125614/https://www.forbes.com/2009/06/19/ceo-executive-hiring-ceonewtork-leadership-nepotism.html |url-status=live }}</ref> Employing intimate people favors perpetuating the ideas or goals of those who employ them, knowing that the people around them will face up to them. However, it can lead to a lack of competent staff or a reduction in productivity because even if the employees are not the best options for their functions, they will be protected by those who employ them.<ref>{{Cite journal |last=Safina |first=Dinara |date=2015 |title=Favouritism and Nepotism in an Organization: Causes and Effects |journal=Procedia Economics and Finance |language=en |volume=23 |pages=630–634 |doi=10.1016/S2212-5671(15)00416-5 |doi-access=free }}</ref> Some businesses forbid nepotism as an ethical matter, considering it too troublesome and disruptive. Most Companies' Codes of Conduct include severe disciplinary sanction for Conflicts of Interest. However, in Nepotistic practices, these are rarely observed or implemented. {{citation needed|date=November 2020}}

==== In academia ==== Nepotism is also frequent in academia where it is frequent for professors to have their partners, and sometimes children, hired by the same faculty in which they work.<ref>{{cite web |title=Nepotism in the Academy Raises Serious Questions |url=https://www.diverseeducation.com/latest-news/article/15103475/nepotism-in-the-academy-raises-serious-questions |website=Diverse: Issues In Higher Education |access-date=15 August 2022 |language=en-us |date=19 October 2018 |archive-date=5 August 2022 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20220805222945/https://www.diverseeducation.com/latest-news/article/15103475/nepotism-in-the-academy-raises-serious-questions |url-status=live }}</ref> In the second half of the XXth century, in the United-States at least, this was far less frequent as universities typically held very strict anti-nepotism policies.<ref>{{cite web |title=Past US Anti-nepotism Rules |url=https://history.nih.gov/display/history/Stadtman+Anti-Nepotism+Rules |website=Diverse: Issues In Higher Education}}</ref> Countries with high levels of corruption and higher education systems with low competition between universities are generally have higher levels of corruption in academia.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Abramo |first1=Giovanni |last2=D'Angelo |first2=Ciriaco Andrea |last3=Rosati |first3=Francesco |title=Relatives in the same university faculty: nepotism or merit? |journal=Scientometrics |date=October 2014 |volume=101 |issue=1 |pages=737–749 |doi=10.1007/s11192-014-1273-z|arxiv=1810.13234 |s2cid=6285408 }}</ref> Italy has been noted for having particularly high levels of nepotism in its academic system, when compared to other developed nations.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Allesina |first1=Stefano |title=Measuring Nepotism through Shared Last Names: The Case of Italian Academia |journal=PLOS ONE |date=3 August 2011 |volume=6 |issue=8 |pages=e21160 |doi=10.1371/journal.pone.0021160|pmid=21826195 |pmc=3149595 |bibcode=2011PLoSO...621160A |doi-access=free }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |last1=Grilli |first1=Jacopo |last2=Allesina |first2=Stefano |title=Last name analysis of mobility, gender imbalance, and nepotism across academic systems |journal=Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences |date=18 July 2017 |volume=114 |issue=29 |pages=7600–7605 |doi=10.1073/pnas.1703513114|pmid=28673985 |pmc=5530677 |bibcode=2017PNAS..114.7600G |doi-access=free }}</ref> Nepotism is often praised for favoring female employment in academia.<ref>{{cite web |title=Anti-nepotism policies and practices |url=https://www.academia.edu/47861504}}</ref>
== Selected examples by country == === Argentina === In [[Argentina]], nepotism is a common practice. Although there have been various attempts at reducing it,<ref>{{cite web |url= https://amp.dw.com/es/nepotismo-el-sue%C3%B1o-argentino/a-42374086 |title= AM – Nepotismo: el "sueño argentino" |work= Deutsche Welle |date= 30 January 2018 |access-date= 20 April 2021 |archive-date= 20 April 2021 |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20210420154722/https://amp.dw.com/es/nepotismo-el-sue%C3%B1o-argentino/a-42374086 |url-status= live }}</ref> it is difficult in a country where state jobs are used as a token of gratitude or party favoritism.
Former president [[Mauricio Macri]] has been investigated for nepotism after allegedly extending a tax amnesty to his family.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://news.yahoo.com/argentine-president-probed-nepotism-tax-amnesty-201053073.html|title=Argentine president probed for nepotism in tax amnesty|publisher=Yahoo News|date=13 December 2006|access-date=12 October 2021|archive-date=27 October 2021|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20211027181525/https://news.yahoo.com/argentine-president-probed-nepotism-tax-amnesty-201053073.html|url-status=live}}</ref>
The [[Kirchnerist]] movement has openly stated that it believes in nepotism, treating meritocracy as a pejorative concept.{{citation needed|date=May 2023}} The government's ministries and secretariats are reportedly plagued with friends, family and supporters of the current party leaders, many of whom have been criticized for being incompetent at their jobs.<ref>{{cite web |url= https://www.clarin.com/politica/polemicas-designaciones-gobierno-alberto-fernandez-siguen-aumento_0_vlFxQlFA.amp.html |title= Denuncias de nepotismo y falta de experiencia para ocupar cargos públicos |publisher= Clarin |date= 25 January 2020 |access-date= 20 April 2021 |archive-date= 20 April 2021 |archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20210420154722/https://www.clarin.com/politica/polemicas-designaciones-gobierno-alberto-fernandez-siguen-aumento_0_vlFxQlFA.amp.html |url-status= live }}</ref>
=== Australia === Shortly after his appointment as the Anglican Archbishop of Sydney in 2001, [[Peter Jensen (bishop)|Peter Jensen]] was accused, in an Australian Broadcasting Corporation interview, of nepotism after nominating his brother [[Phillip Jensen]] as Dean of Sydney and appointing his wife Christine Jensen to an official position in the Sydney diocese.<ref>{{cite web |date=18 November 2002 |title=AM – Archbishop Jensen accused of nepotism |url=http://www.abc.net.au/am/stories/s728866.htm |access-date=22 June 2012 |work=Australian Broadcasting Corporation |archive-date=18 February 2010 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100218073022/http://www.abc.net.au/am/stories/s728866.htm |url-status=live }}</ref>

[[Football Federation Australia]] was led by [[Frank Lowy]] from its inception in 2004 until his [[term limit]] exit in 2015. His son, [[Steven Lowy]], who had little direct involvement in high level sports governance was nominated as his replacement by Frank, and was elected unopposed by a board strongly loyal to Frank. Steven's introduction exacerbated existing governance issues, with factional opposition lead by [[City Football Group]] causing [[FIFA]] intervention to be threatened. Eventually governance reforms were forced through despite opposition from the Lowy family, and it ended with Steven Lowy resigning from the role. === Belgium === Over the past decade, criticism has been growing over the creation of political dynasties in Belgium. This phenomenon has been explained by the fact that prominent party members control the ranking of candidates on party lists for elections and a candidate's place on a list determines who is elected. Another justification for the phenomenon is the importance of name recognition for collecting votes.<ref name=autogenerated1>{{cite web |url=http://www.telegraaf.nl/buitenland/3376470/__Politiek_Belgie_is_familiezaak__.html?p=7,1 |title=Politiek België is familiezaak – Buitenland – Telegraaf.nl [24 uur actueel, ook mobiel] [buitenland] |publisher=Telegraaf.nl |access-date=6 March 2011 |archive-date=8 June 2011 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110608050210/http://www.telegraaf.nl/buitenland/3376470/__Politiek_Belgie_is_familiezaak__.html?p=7,1 |url-status=live }}</ref>
Claims of nepotism have been made against [[Bruno Tobback]], the son of senator and former minister [[Louis Tobback]], a member of the Flemish socialists, became the Belgian federal government's minister for the pensions and environment at 35 in 2005.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.ipe.com/magazine/tobback-making-his-mark_17630.php#.UcPF2ZzgUoI | title=Tobback: making his mark | publisher=IPE International Publishers Limited | work=Investment & Pensions Europe | date=1 March 2005 | access-date=20 June 2013 | author=Martin Hurst}}</ref> [[Alexander De Croo]], the son of former speaker of the Belgian parliament Herman De Croo, ran for the leadership of his father's party Open VLD at age 33.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.gva.be/nieuws/binnenland/aid874229/alexander-de-croo-wil-voorzitter-open-vld-worden.aspx?cmt=all |title=Alexander De Croo wil voorzitter Open Vld worden |date=27 October 2009 |publisher=Gva.be |access-date=6 March 2011 |archive-date=11 May 2011 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110511132817/http://www.gva.be/nieuws/binnenland/aid874229/alexander-de-croo-wil-voorzitter-open-vld-worden.aspx?cmt=all |url-status=live }}</ref> Finally there is the example of [[Maya Detiège]], the daughter of former mayor of the city of [[Antwerp]] Leona Detiège, who herself is the daughter of the former mayor of [[Antwerp]] Frans Detiège.<ref name=autogenerated1 /> Among other examples are former minister [[Freya Van den Bossche|Freya Van Den Bossche]] and senator [[Jean-Jacques De Gucht]], being the daughter and son of respectively former minister [[Luc Van den Bossche|Luc Vandenbossche]] and former minister [[Karel De Gucht]].
=== Cambodia === [[Prime Minister of Cambodia|Prime Minister]] [[Hun Sen]] and senior members of [[Parliament of Cambodia|Parliament]] are known for their hand in getting family members into government positions. ===Indonesia=== [[Suharto]], Indonesia's second president, is involved in nepotism, alongside corruption and [[collusion]] (together, they are known as the ''KKN'' in {{lang-id|korupsi, kolusi, dan nepotisme}}). Companies belonging to Suharto's children, particularly Siti Hardiyanti Rukmana ("Tutut"), Hutomo Mandala Putra ("Tommy"), and Bambang Trihatmodjo, were given lucrative government contracts and protected from market competition by monopolies. Examples include the toll-expressway company [[:id:Jasamarga|Jasamarga]] (monopolized by Tutut), the national car project [[Timor]] (monopolized by Bambang and Tommy), and the cinema market (monopolized by [[:id:21 Cineplex|21 Cineplex]], which is owned by Suharto's cousin Sudwikatmono). The family is said to control about {{Cvt|36000|km2}} of real estate in Indonesia, including {{Cvt|100000|m2}} of prime office space in Jakarta and nearly 40% of the land in [[East Timor]]. Additionally, Suharto's family members received free shares in 1,251 of Indonesia's most lucrative domestic companies (mostly run by Suharto's ethnic-Chinese cronies), while foreign-owned companies were encouraged to establish "strategic partnerships" with the former Indonesian president's family companies.<ref name="BBC_20040325">{{cite news | url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/business/3567745.stm | title=Suharto tops corruption rankings | work=BBC News | date=25 March 2004 | access-date=4 February 2006 | archive-date=13 November 2020 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20201113042444/http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/business/3567745.stm | url-status=live }}</ref><ref name="Global Corruption Report">{{cite web |url=http://www.transparency.org/content/download/4459/26786/file/Introduction_to_political_corruption.pdf |title=Global Corruption Report |publisher=Transparency International |access-date=6 August 2009 |archive-date=4 July 2007 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070704093500/http://www.transparency.org/content/download/4459/26786/file/Introduction_to_political_corruption.pdf |url-status=dead }}</ref>
=== Mauritius === {{Overly detailed|section|details=the text contains unnecessary details, is very long compared to the other sections, and would seriously benefit from being trimmed|date=February 2021}} Nepotism is common in [[Politics of Mauritius|Mauritian politics]], with many relatives and friends of high-ranking politicians being appointed high-ranking positions and associated companies being granted government contracts.
Since the [[1948 Mauritian general election|first democratic elections in 1948]], the field of politics in Mauritius has been marked by a handful of families who have controlled the four major political parties which exist to this day. They are often referred to as the "modern dynasties" of Mauritian politics such as the Duval, Bérenger, Curé, Uteem, Mohamed, Boolell, Ramgoolam and Jugnauth families. The Boolell family's involvement in politics started with [[Satcam Boolell]] in 1955, paving the way for his son [[Arvin Boolell]], nephews Satish Boolell, Anil Gayan, and Sanjay Bhuckory, and son-in-law Sushil Kushiram to enter politics. The Duval dynasty started with ex-[[Lord mayor]] and minister Gaetan Duval, followed by his sons Xavier and Richard as well as grandson Adrien. Lall Jugnauth was the first of his clan to enter politics in the 1950s and was followed by his cousins Aneerood and Ashock as well as nephew Pravind. ==== Nepotism under Anerood Jugnauth ==== In May 1992, the [[Bank of Mauritius]] issued a Rs 20 note which featured the portrait of [[Sarojini Jugnauth]], wife of Prime Minister [[Anerood Jugnauth]]. The portrait was considered to be a birthday gift from Anerood to his wife. This developed into a major controversy, which led to Anerood confirming in parliament that he had approved the issue of the new note. He apologised to the population and stated he would not commit such a mistake in the future.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.lemauricien.com/article/il-y-eu-vingt-ans-mois-dernier-laffaire-du-billet-rs-20|title=IL Y A EU VINGT ANS, LE MOIS DERNIER: L'affaire du billet de Rs 20 – Le Mauricien|date=6 May 2012|work=Le Mauricien|access-date=14 June 2018|language=fr-FR|archive-date=14 June 2018|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20180614194800/http://www.lemauricien.com/article/il-y-eu-vingt-ans-mois-dernier-laffaire-du-billet-rs-20/|url-status=live}}</ref>
Despite her defeat in the 2014 general elections, [[Maya Hanoomanjee]] became Speaker of the National Assembly, Sarojini Jugnauth's niece. === Singapore === {{Expand section|date=November 2020}} [[Government of Singapore|Singapore's government]] has been the target of numerous charges of nepotism, with several members of the [[Prime Minister of Singapore|Prime Minister]]'s family holding high ranking posts. === Sri Lanka === {{See also|Rajapaksa family}} Former President of Sri Lanka, [[Mahinda Rajapaksa]], has been accused of nepotism, appointing three brothers to run important ministries and giving out other political positions to relatives, regardless of their merit. During his presidency, the Rajapaksa family held the ministries of [[Ministry of Finance and Planning (Sri Lanka)|finance]], [[defence minister|defence]], [[Ministry of Ports and Aviation (Sri Lanka)|ports and aviation]], and [[Ministry of Highways and Road Development (Sri Lanka)|highways and road development]]. The president's brother, [[Gotabhaya Rajapaksa]], was given the post of [[Ministry of Defence (Sri Lanka)|Defence Secretary]]. He also controlled the armed forces, the police and the Coast Guard, and was responsible for immigration and emigration. Rajapaksa appointed his brother [[Basil Rajapaksa]] as minister of [[Ministry of Youth Empowerment and Socio Economic Development (Sri Lanka)|Economic Development]]. Together, the Rajapaksa brothers controlled over 70% of Sri Lanka's public budget. Mahinda Rajapaksa's eldest brother, [[Chamal Rajapaksa]], was appointed as the [[Speaker of the Parliament of Sri Lanka]], and has held many other posts before, while his eldest son, Namal Rajapaksa, is also a member of the parliament and holds undisclosed portfolios.<ref>{{cite news | url=http://www.economist.com/node/9299003?story_id=9299003 | newspaper=The Economist | title=A war strange as fiction | date=7 June 2007 | access-date=16 January 2011 | archive-date=1 July 2017 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170701154522/http://www.economist.com/node/9299003?story_id=9299003 | url-status=live }}</ref><ref name="atimes1">{{cite news |author=Sudha Ramachandran |url=http://www.atimes.com/atimes/South_Asia/LK11Df02.html |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101113055510/http://www.atimes.com/atimes/South_Asia/LK11Df02.html |archive-date=13 November 2010 |work=Asia Times |title=Feuds start in Sri Lanka's first family |date=11 November 2010 |access-date=6 March 2011}}</ref>
Others include: his nephew, [[Shashindra Rajapaksa]], who is the former [[Chief minister of Uva]]; one of his cousins, former Sri Lankan ambassador to the [[United States]], [[Jaliya Wickramasuriya]]; and another cousin, [[Udayanga Weeratunga]], who is the former ambassador to [[Russia]]. [[File:Trump With Family February 1 2016.jpg|thumb|400px|The Trump family]] In 2017, President [[Donald Trump]] was accused of nepotism after appointing both his son-in-law [[Jared Kushner]] and his daughter [[Ivanka Trump|Ivanka]] (married to Kushner) into [[Senior Advisor to the President of the United States|advisory roles to the president]].<ref>{{cite news |author=Alan Yuhas |title=Trump names son-in-law Jared Kushner as senior adviser, testing anti-nepotism law |date=10 January 2017 |newspaper=The Guardian |url=https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2017/jan/09/jared-kushner-senior-adviser-donald-trump |access-date=4 February 2023 |archive-date=9 October 2019 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20191009125621/https://www.theguardian.com/us-news/2017/jan/09/jared-kushner-senior-adviser-donald-trump |url-status=live }}</ref> In 2020, President Trump appointed his son [[Eric Trump]]'s brother-in-law, Kyle Yunaska, to the position of [[NASA]] Deputy Chief of Staff. Yunaska holds a 2009 MBA and a 2007 Bachelor of Science in Management and Physics, both from [[East Carolina University]]. Yunaska was a paid government employee.{{citation needed|date=August 2020}}

=== Venezuela === Nepotism is known to be practiced by President of the Venezuela National Assembly, [[Cilia Flores]]. Nine positions in the National Assembly were filled by Flores' family members, including a mother-in-law, aunt, three siblings, a cousin and her mother, and two nephews.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2007/02/18/world/americas/18iht-venez.html?_r=0|title=Chávez family dogged by nepotism claims|date=18 February 2007|work=The New York Times|access-date=20 June 2013|author=Simon Romero|archive-date=5 August 2017|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170805145626/http://www.nytimes.com/2007/02/18/world/americas/18iht-venez.html?_r=0|url-status=live}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://buscador.eluniversal.com/2008/07/08/pol_ava_cilia-flores-niega-i_08A1777279.shtml|title=Nacional y Política - eluniversal.com|publisher=Buscador.eluniversal.com|language=es|access-date=6 March 2011|archive-date=15 May 2011|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110515041514/http://buscador.eluniversal.com/2008/07/08/pol_ava_cilia-flores-niega-i_08A1777279.shtml|url-status=live}}</ref>

== Types of partiality == Nepotism refers to partiality to family whereas [[cronyism]] refers to partiality to an associate or [[friend]]. [[In-group favoritism|Favoritism]], the broadest of the terms, refers to partiality based upon being part of a favored group, rather than job performance.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://www.scu.edu/ethics/practicing/focusareas/government_ethics/introduction/cronyism.html | title=Favoritism, Cronyism, and Nepotism | publisher=Santa Clara University | access-date=20 June 2013 | author=Judy Nadler and Miriam Schulman | archive-date=12 June 2013 | archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130612111602/http://www.scu.edu/ethics/practicing/focusareas/government_ethics/introduction/cronyism.html | url-status=live }}</ref>
